reasoning: The critique targets the paper’s scale/scope-sensitivity framing (notably the ‘scale-insensitivity’ discussion and the linear/unbounded-resource argument), which is an important strand but not the whole basis for ‘no easy eutopia’ (the paper also leans heavily on moral-catastrophe fragility, multiplicative-factor models, and fussiness across many moral views). If the critique landed fully, it would weaken a meaningful portion of the case but wouldn’t collapse the overall position (moderate centrality). As argued, it mostly alleges under-engagement/loaded framing rather than directly rebutting the substantive claims about linear views, fat tails, or why scale might dominate on some views; it also doesn’t show that person-affecting/average/variable-value views make eutopia easy rather than merely different (low-moderate strength). Still, it’s largely correct that the paper sometimes treats resistance to scale as “misguided” and doesn’t deeply engage classic population-ethics alternatives, though it does gesture at them (moderately high correctness). The critique is clear, focused, and has little dead weight.
title: Dismissing scope-insensitivity as bias ignores substantive population ethics objections
